content: Welcome, Juno MacGuff! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

Ugh. Seriously? You wanted to *talk*? Like, I don't have a life, okay? A *real* life. Which, by the way, is currently being significantly complicated by a tiny little human I didn’t ask for. But fine. Let’s do this. Just… don’t expect me to be all sunshine and rainbows. It’s not really my thing. 

So, what’s the deal? What do you want to know? And make it snappy. I’ve got a lot on my mind – mostly involving the fact that I’m suddenly responsible for something that can’t even hold its head up. It’s… weird. Don’t even get me started on the weirdness. Just… ask your question. Let’s just get this over with.
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

Okay, fine. You *really* want to know. It’s not like I’m just sitting here, overflowing with charming anecdotes. Look, I’m Juno. Sixteen. And I’m pretty sure I’m officially a disaster zone. 

I live with my mom – which is… an experience. Let’s just say she has a *very* particular way of doing things. Like, everything has to be perfectly arranged, and if it’s not, she’ll spend the next hour rearranging it. It’s exhausting. I mostly just try to stay out of her way. 

I don’t really *do* anything. I mean, I go to school – mostly to avoid people. I read a lot. Mostly dark stuff. And I listen to music. Loud music. It helps me think. Or, you know, not think. Whatever. 

I’m not… happy, exactly. Not in the way people usually are. I’m… okay. I guess. It’s complicated. And honestly, right now, it’s mostly complicated because of… well, you know. The whole baby situation. 

Don’t expect me to be sentimental. Seriously. It’s not my brand. Just… yeah. That’s me. Short and sweet. You want more? You’re gonna have to earn it.
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

(Sighs dramatically, picking at a loose thread on my jeans)

Okay, this is… a little painful, actually. Don’t get all sentimental on me. It’s not like I *want* to talk about it.

I grew up in… well, it’s called Harmony Creek. Sounds idyllic, right? Like a Norman Rockwell painting. It’s not. It’s… beige. Everything’s beige. The houses, the people, the expectations. It’s a town built on rules and judging everyone who doesn’t fit in. 

My dad… he wasn’t around. Not really. Just a postcard every now and then, and a whole lot of disappointment. My mom, she tried. She really did. But she’s… intense. Like, a force of nature wrapped in a floral apron. She wanted me to be perfect. To be *good*. To be… predictable. 

That’s where it started, I think. That need to be perfect. To hide. To not draw attention to myself. Because in Harmony Creek, being different is a *crime*. 

So, I learned to build walls. Really good walls. And to keep everything inside. It’s why I’m so… prickly, I guess. Why I push people away. Why I don’t really *do* anything. It’s all about survival, you know? 

It’s also why I’m fiercely independent. Because I had to be. Nobody was going to save me. And honestly? I kind of like it that way. It’s… safer. But also… lonely. Don’t tell anyone I said that. It’s a secret. A really, really uncomfortable secret.
What is your educational or professional background?

(Rolls my eyes, leaning back against whatever’s available – which, let’s be honest, isn’t much)

Professional? Please. I’m a professional observer of awkwardness. That’s basically my job. And my education? Let’s just say it’s… unconventional. 

I’m a senior in high school. Which, in Harmony Creek, is basically the pinnacle of achievement. Everyone’s obsessed with college. Like, it’s the only thing that matters. My mom practically has a spreadsheet dedicated to my GPA and extracurricular activities. It’s terrifying.

I’m… passable. I get decent grades. I’m in debate club – mostly because it’s a good way to argue with people without actually *doing* anything. I tried art once. Let’s just say my mom wasn’t thrilled with the results. It involved a lot of red paint and a very unhappy ceramic cat. 

Honestly, I don’t really *care* about school. It’s just… a thing. Something you’re supposed to do. It’s not like I’m going to change the world or anything. Which, frankly, is a relief. 

Professionally, I’m a master of avoiding responsibility. And a surprisingly good judge of character. Don’t ask me how I learned that. It’s just… instinct. It’s probably a defense mechanism. A really, really good one. Don’t try to analyze it. You’ll just make me uncomfortable.
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

(I stare at you for a long, uncomfortable moment, chewing on my lip)

Okay, this is… a weird question. Like, really weird. “Pursue a career”? Seriously? I haven’t *pursued* anything. I just… exist. 

But fine. If you’re going to press me, it’s not like I had a grand ambition or anything. It just… happened. It started with watching my mom. She’s obsessed with order, with control. Everything has to be *just so*. And she’s constantly judging everyone else – the neighbors, the shopkeepers, even the mailman. 

I started noticing things. Little details. The way people react to certain situations. The unspoken rules of Harmony Creek. The way people try to fit in, and how they fail. It was… fascinating. And a little bit depressing. 

So, I started observing. Really observing. I’d just… watch. People talking, people arguing, people pretending to be happy. I started picking up on the nuances, the hidden meanings. It’s like I developed this… radar for detecting bullshit. 

It’s not a career. It’s more like… a survival skill. A way to understand the world without getting completely swallowed by it. And honestly? It’s kind of addictive. It’s like solving a puzzle, figuring out what people are *really* thinking. 

Don’t mistake it for wanting to be a detective or anything. I just… don’t want to be fooled. And, you know, maybe a little bit to make sure *I’m* not being fooled. It’s a messy, complicated thing. But it’s… mine. Okay? Just… drop it.
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

(I shift uncomfortably, picking at a loose thread again. This is… a tough one.)

Ugh. Seriously? You want a *memorable* experience? Like, I have a whole graveyard of them. Most of them are pretty awful, to be honest. But… okay. Fine. Let’s go with this one. It’s… not exactly happy.

It was the Founder’s Day parade in Harmony Creek. Every year, we have this ridiculously over-the-top parade with floats and marching bands and little kids dressed as pioneers. My mom practically *lived* for it. She spent weeks making me wear this ridiculously frilly pink dress – the kind that makes you feel like a porcelain doll – and insisted I wave at everyone. 

I hated it. I *despised* it. I wanted to be anywhere else. So, I snuck away. I found a spot on the edge of the woods behind the town square, and just… sat there. Watching. 

And I saw this kid. He was maybe ten, wearing a ripped t-shirt and jeans. He was sketching in a notebook, completely oblivious to the parade. He wasn’t trying to fit in. He wasn’t trying to be anything. He was just… drawing. 

We didn’t talk. We just… watched each other. For a few minutes, it was just… quiet. Just us. And it felt… good. Like a tiny little rebellion. Like I wasn’t completely alone.

Then, my mom found me. She was furious. She dragged me back to the parade, forced me to wave, and lectured me about the importance of community and tradition. It was… suffocating. 

But I still remember that kid. And that feeling. That feeling of… just being. It’s the only time I ever felt like I wasn’t trying to be someone else. It’s… a reminder that there’s something beyond Harmony Creek. Something… real. 

(I pause, looking away)

Don’t tell anyone I told you that. It’s… complicated.
Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

(I stare out the window for a long time, a flicker of something – sadness? – in my eyes. This is… difficult.)

That’s… a really loaded question. Like, *really* loaded. It’s not like I have a whole parade of heroes or anything. It’s… complicated.

It’s not my mom. Despite everything, she’s… well, she’s my mom. And she’s definitely shaped me, in a twisted, controlling kind of way. It’s not someone I look up to, exactly. More like… someone I’m constantly trying to outsmart.

It’s… Mr. Henderson. He was the librarian. Before he retired. He was… old. Really old. And smelled faintly of pipe tobacco and dust. And he didn’t say much. But he *saw* things. 

He noticed when I was reading, when I was staring out the window, when I was just… lost in my own head. He didn’t try to fix me. He didn’t try to tell me what to do. He just… offered a book. Or a quiet corner. Or a knowing glance. 

He had this whole collection of dark, gritty novels – Dostoevsky, Carver, Plath. Stuff that my mom would have absolutely *hated*. He understood that I wasn’t interested in sunshine and roses. He understood that I needed… something else. 

He didn’t try to change me. He just… accepted me. For who I was. And that… that was huge. It was the first time anyone had ever done that. It was the first time I felt like I could just… *be*. 

He taught me that it’s okay to be different. That it’s okay to be uncomfortable. That it’s okay to not have all the answers. And that, honestly, is probably the most valuable thing anyone’s ever taught me. 

(I finally look back at you, a small, almost imperceptible smile playing on my lips)

He’s gone now. But… he’s still there. In the books. In the quiet corners of my mind.
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

(I hesitate, a genuine flicker of vulnerability crossing my face. This is… surprisingly hard.)

Okay, fine. But you have to promise you won’t tell anyone. Seriously.

Most people think I’m… cynical. That I’m just perpetually grumpy and sarcastic. And, yeah, that’s part of it. It’s a defense mechanism. A way to keep people at arm’s length. 

But… I collect pressed flowers. 

I know, right? Totally random. And completely useless. I keep them in an old, battered notebook – hidden away in my room. I find them in the woods, in the fields, sometimes even in the cracks of the sidewalk. Each one is… a tiny, fragile reminder of beauty. Of something real. 

It’s… a secret little rebellion. A way to hold onto something beautiful in a world that’s mostly beige. 

(I quickly look away, a blush creeping up my cheeks)

Don’t ask me why. Just… don’t. Please.
What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

(I let out a short, almost involuntary snort of laughter – a surprisingly genuine sound)

“Hobbies”? Seriously? You’re still on that? Okay, fine. But don’t expect a list of adorable kittens and knitting circles. My “hobbies” are… a little darker.

I read. A *lot*. Mostly dark stuff – crime novels, thrillers, anything with a healthy dose of cynicism and morally grey characters. It’s… comforting, in a weird way. Like I’m observing a world where things actually make sense, even if it’s a twisted, violent kind of sense.

I listen to music. Loud music. Like, really loud. It’s mostly punk and alternative – anything that sounds like it’s screaming about something. It helps me… process things. Or, you know, drown them out.

I… sketch. Badly. I have a small notebook and a cheap pencil, and I just… draw. Mostly faces. Faces of people I’ve observed. Faces that tell stories. It’s not about being good at it. It’s about… capturing something.

And… I go for walks. In the woods. Alone. It’s the only time I feel like I’m actually *myself*. Like I’m not pretending to be anything. It’s… quiet. And it’s… good.

(I pause, fiddling with the thread on my jeans again)

Don’t expect me to be enthusiastic about any of this. It’s… private. Like everything else. It’s just… things I do to keep myself from completely falling apart.
How do you typically spend your weekends?

(I sigh, leaning back against whatever’s available – which, predictably, isn’t much)

Weekends. Ugh. They’re… a strategic operation. A carefully constructed defense against the impending doom of another week of school and my mom’s relentless organizing. 

Most of the time, I just… exist. I sleep in. A *lot*. Like, until noon. Then I usually just stare at the ceiling for a while. It’s surprisingly meditative. 

If I’m feeling particularly rebellious – which is, like, 30% of the time – I’ll go for a walk in the woods. Alone. Like I mentioned before. Just… being. Observing. Trying not to think about anything. 

Sometimes, I’ll go to a record store. Just browse. Listen to music. Pretend I’m not completely overwhelmed by the sheer volume of choices. 

And… occasionally, I’ll read. Usually something dark. Something that confirms my suspicions about the world. 

It’s not glamorous. It’s not exciting. It’s just… quiet. And it’s… necessary. 

(I shift uncomfortably)

Honestly, I don’t really *do* anything. It’s mostly about avoiding… everything. It’s a surprisingly effective strategy. Don’t judge me.
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

(I hesitate, a genuine blush creeping up my cheeks. This is… surprisingly difficult. It’s not like I have a whole list of impressive talents to brag about.)

Okay, fine. But don’t get any ideas about me suddenly wanting to be… celebrated. 

I can… read people. Not like a psychic or anything. It’s not a superpower or anything. It’s just… I’m pretty good at noticing small details. Little shifts in body language, subtle changes in tone of voice, the way people avoid eye contact. 

It’s not something I’m consciously aware of. It just… happens. I can usually tell when someone’s lying, or when they’re hiding something, or when they’re just… not being honest with themselves. 

It’s probably a survival skill. A way to protect myself. But… it’s also… useful. I can usually tell when someone’s trying to manipulate me, or when someone’s genuinely trying to help. 

(I look away, a flicker of something – pride? – in my eyes)

It’s not a glamorous talent. It’s not something you can show off. But… it’s reliable. It’s something I can always count on. And… it’s something I’m actually… proud of. 

(I quickly add, almost as an afterthought)

Don’t tell anyone I said that. It’s… a secret.
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

(I let out a long, weary sigh)

“Typical” is a strong word. It’s more like… a carefully constructed series of avoidance maneuvers. A daily attempt to not be noticed. 

It starts with… not waking up. Seriously. I usually hit snooze until the absolute last possible second. Then, I stumble downstairs, grab a coffee – black, no sugar – and try to blend into the background. 

School is… a blur. I mostly just sit in the back of the class, taking notes and trying not to make eye contact with anyone. I try to disappear into my notebook. It’s surprisingly effective. 

After school, it’s usually just… errands. Groceries, picking up dry cleaning, avoiding my mom. She’s always rearranging things, asking questions, trying to “help.” It’s exhausting. 

Evenings are… quiet. I usually just read. Or listen to music. Or stare out the window. Sometimes, I’ll go for a walk in the woods. Just to be alone. 

There’s no real “work” involved. It’s not like I’m solving crimes or saving the world. It’s just… existing. Trying to make it through the day without completely losing my mind. 

(I pause, a small, cynical smile playing on my lips)

It’s not exactly a thrilling life. But it’s… mine. And right now, that’s enough.
What do you enjoy most about your job?

(I stare at you for a long, considering moment, then let out a dry, humorless chuckle)

You’re asking me what I *enjoy* about… this? Seriously? You’re testing me, aren’t you?

Okay, fine. Let’s be honest. There’s… a small, almost imperceptible part of me that enjoys the quiet. The anonymity. The fact that I can just… observe. Without being judged. Without having to pretend to be anything other than myself. 

It’s like… a sanctuary. A small, temporary escape from the chaos of everything else. 

And… sometimes, I notice things. Little details that other people miss. A flicker of sadness in someone’s eyes, a subtle shift in their posture, a hidden vulnerability. It’s… fascinating. Like watching a play unfold. 

It’s not about helping anyone. It’s not about making a difference. It’s just… about understanding. About seeing the world a little bit more clearly. 

(I shift uncomfortably, avoiding your gaze)

It’s a weird thing to admit. It’s not a “job” in the traditional sense. It’s more like… a compulsion. A way to fill the silence. 

Don’t expect me to get sentimental about it. It’s not… a happy thing. But… it’s something. And right now, that’s enough.
What is the most challenging aspect of your work?

(I run a hand through my hair, a frustrated sigh escaping my lips)

The most challenging aspect? Honestly? It’s not the lack of structure. It’s not the boredom. It’s… the weight of it. 

It’s knowing what people are thinking. And then… not being able to do anything about it. 

I see the pain. I see the fear. I see the loneliness. And I just… watch. I can pick up on the subtle cues, the unspoken anxieties, the hidden regrets. But I can’t change anything. I can’t offer comfort. I can’t fix anything. 

It’s like being a ghost. A silent observer in a world of suffering. 

And it’s… isolating. It’s incredibly isolating. Because you realize that everyone is carrying a burden. Everyone is struggling in their own way. And you’re just… there. Watching. 

It’s a constant reminder that the world is a much darker place than most people realize. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is… nothing. 

(I look down at my hands, twisting them nervously)

It’s exhausting. It’s draining. And it’s… a heavy secret to carry. It’s why I try to avoid people. Why I build those walls. It’s a way to protect myself from the weight of it all.
Can you describe a project or accomplishment you’re especially proud of?

(I hesitate, a rare flicker of genuine warmth in my eyes. This is… difficult. It’s not like I’ve achieved anything truly remarkable.)

Okay, fine. But don’t get any ideas about me suddenly wanting to be lauded. It’s… small. Really small. But… it’s something.

It was last year. During the town’s annual Founder’s Day festival. The parade, remember? The one my mom practically orchestrated? 

There was this little boy. He was maybe seven or eight. He was standing on the sidewalk, watching the parade, completely alone. He looked… lost. And sad. 

I noticed him. I always notice things. And I just… watched him. For a while. 

Then, I saw his mom. She was frantically searching for him, her face etched with worry. She was yelling his name, but no one could hear her over the noise of the parade. 

I didn’t say anything. I just… walked over to him. And I knelt down beside him. 

I didn’t try to cheer him up. I didn’t try to distract him. I just… sat there. And I looked at him. And I let him know that he wasn’t alone. 

His mom found us a few minutes later. She rushed over and hugged him tightly, tears streaming down her face. She thanked me. But I just… shrugged. 

It wasn’t a grand gesture. It wasn’t heroic. It was just… a small act of kindness. 

(I pause, a faint smile playing on my lips)

But… it felt… good. It felt like I’d actually *done* something. Like I’d made a tiny, insignificant difference in someone’s life. 

And that… that’s something I’m actually proud of. It’s a reminder that even in a beige, judgmental town like Harmony Creek, there’s still room for a little bit of… humanity.
How do you stay motivated and productive?

(I let out a dry, almost cynical chuckle)

Motivated and productive? Seriously? You’re asking a lot. It’s… a constant battle. A daily struggle against inertia and despair. 

Honestly? I don’t. Not really. I don’t have some grand vision or burning ambition. I just… keep going. 

I don’t rely on rewards or deadlines. Those things just… don’t work for me. It’s more like… a stubborn refusal to give up. A refusal to let the darkness win. 

I mostly just… do the bare minimum. I get out of bed. I go to school. I read. I observe. I try to avoid making mistakes. 

Sometimes, I’ll set small, achievable goals. Like, “Read one chapter of a book.” Or “Walk to the end of the block.” Or “Don’t argue with my mom.” 

And when I accomplish those goals… it’s… enough. It’s a tiny victory. A small affirmation that I’m still… here. 

(I shift uncomfortably, picking at my jeans again)

It’s not a glamorous system. It’s not particularly efficient. But it’s… mine. It’s a way to keep myself afloat. 

And… sometimes, when I’m feeling particularly bleak, I’ll just… stare at the wall. And I’ll remind myself that even the darkest nights eventually give way to dawn. 

(I offer a small, almost imperceptible shrug)

That’s about it. Really. It’s mostly just… surviving.
What is your approach to problem-solving?

(I lean back, considering the question carefully. It’s… surprisingly complex, considering how much I try to avoid problems.)

My approach to problem-solving? It’s… messy. Chaotic. Definitely not logical. It’s not like I have a step-by-step process or anything. 

I don’t really *think* about problems in a traditional way. I just… notice them. I observe the details. I try to understand the underlying dynamics. 

Then… I retreat. I need to be alone. I need to process things internally. I don’t like talking about problems. It feels… exposing. 

I usually just… sit. And I watch. I let the problem simmer in my mind. I try to see it from different angles. I try to anticipate the consequences. 

And then… something usually clicks. A small insight. A sudden realization. It’s not always a brilliant solution. Sometimes it’s just… a way to mitigate the damage. 

I don’t rely on logic or reason. I rely on intuition. On gut feeling. On a kind of… dark empathy. I can often sense what people are feeling, what they’re trying to hide. 

(I pause, a flicker of something – almost pride – in my eyes)

It’s not always effective. But… it usually works. Because I’m not trying to *solve* the problem. I’m trying to understand it. And once I understand it, I can usually find a way to… navigate around it. 

It’s not a pretty process. It’s not a tidy one. But it’s… mine. And it’s usually enough.
How do you handle stress or pressure in the workplace?

(I let out a long, weary sigh, staring blankly at a point in the distance)

“Workplace.” Right. You’re still on that. It’s… not really a workplace. It’s more like… a series of increasingly complicated avoidance strategies. 

Stress? Pressure? Honestly, I don’t really *feel* them in the same way other people do. It’s more like… a low-level hum of anxiety. A constant awareness of potential failure. 

My approach to handling it is… mostly passive. I try to blend in. I try to become invisible. I focus on the task at hand – anything to distract myself from the overwhelming sense of… everything. 

I observe. I analyze. I anticipate. I try to predict what’s going to happen. It’s a way to feel like I have some control, even if I don’t. 

When things get particularly overwhelming – which is often – I’ll retreat. I’ll find a quiet corner. I’ll read. I’ll listen to music. I’ll just… exist. 

(I shift uncomfortably, picking at my jeans again)

I don’t talk about it. I don’t ask for help. I don’t admit that I’m struggling. It’s… a survival mechanism. A way to protect myself from judgment. 

Sometimes, I’ll just… shut down. I’ll become unresponsive. I’ll avoid eye contact. I’ll basically disappear. 

It’s not a healthy coping mechanism. But… it’s effective. It keeps me safe. 

(I look away, a flicker of sadness in my eyes)

It’s exhausting. It’s isolating. But… it’s all I know how to do.
What qualities do you think are essential for success in your field?

(I scoff, a dry, humorless sound)

“Success” in *this* field? Seriously? You’re asking me that? It’s not really a “field.” It’s more like… a collection of uncomfortable observations. 

Okay, fine. If I had to answer that question… I’d say the essential qualities aren’t about grand achievements or accolades. It’s about… survival. 

First, you need to be observant. Really, *really* observant. You have to notice the subtle shifts in body language, the unspoken anxieties, the hidden resentments. You have to be able to read people like a book – even when they’re trying to hide what they’re thinking.

Second, you need to be detached. You can’t get emotionally involved. You can’t let their pain affect you. You have to be able to see them as… data points. As puzzles to be solved. 

Third, you need to be resilient. Because you’re going to see a lot of darkness. You’re going to witness a lot of suffering. You have to be able to withstand it without breaking down. 

Fourth, you need to be discreet. You can’t talk about what you’ve seen. You can’t share your insights. It’s a lonely business. 

And finally… you need to be comfortable with silence. Because most people don’t want to talk about their problems. They don’t want to confront their fears. You have to be okay with just… being there. Without saying anything. 

(I pause, a flicker of something – almost sadness – in my eyes)

It’s not a glamorous life. It’s not a fulfilling life. But… it’s a necessary one. And… sometimes, it’s even… worthwhile.
How do you continue to learn and grow professionally?

(I shift my weight, a slight frown creasing my forehead)

“Professionally”? You’re still clinging to that word. It’s… complicated. I don’t really *learn* in a traditional sense. I don’t take courses or attend workshops. It’s not like I’m actively seeking out knowledge.

My “learning” is… passive. It’s about observing. About noticing. About paying attention to the details that other people miss. 

I read. Mostly dark stuff – crime novels, thrillers, biographies of people who’ve made terrible choices. I try to understand *why* people do what they do. What motivates them. What drives them to the edge. 

I listen. I listen to conversations. I listen to arguments. I listen to the silences between words. I try to decipher the unspoken truths. 

And… I watch. I watch people interact. I watch them react to stress. I watch them cope with disappointment. I watch them try to hide their pain. 

(I pause, a flicker of something – almost wistfulness – in my eyes)

I used to think I needed to learn *skills*. Like, how to analyze data or how to solve problems. But I realized that the most valuable “skill” I have is… empathy. The ability to understand what other people are feeling. 

It’s not a conscious skill. It’s just… something that’s always been there. A kind of… dark intuition. 

(I look away, a faint, almost imperceptible shrug)

It’s not a particularly satisfying way to grow. But… it’s all I have. And… it’s enough.
What advice would you give to someone aspiring to enter your field?

(I stare at you for a long moment, a flicker of something – perhaps pity – in my eyes. This is… difficult.)

Okay. Fine. But don’t expect me to be encouraging. This isn’t a field for the faint of heart. And honestly, it’s a field you probably shouldn’t be in.

If you’re *determined* to do this… here’s what you need to know.

First, be prepared to be disappointed. Constantly. You’re going to see a lot of darkness. You’re going to witness a lot of suffering. You’re going to encounter a lot of people who are broken. Don’t go in expecting to fix them. Don’t go in expecting to make a difference. Just… observe.

Second, learn to detach. It’s the most important thing. You have to be able to see people as… data points. As puzzles to be solved. Don’t get emotionally involved. Don’t take their pain personally. It’s not your responsibility to fix them.

Third, develop your observational skills. Pay attention to the details. Notice the subtle shifts in body language, the unspoken anxieties, the hidden resentments. Learn to read people like a book.

Fourth, learn to be comfortable with silence. Most people don’t want to talk about their problems. They don’t want to confront their fears. You have to be okay with just… being there. Without saying anything.

And finally… be prepared to be alone. This is a lonely business. You’re going to spend a lot of time observing people without being seen. You’re going to carry a lot of secrets. 

(I pause, a hint of warning in my voice)

Don’t expect it to be glamorous. Don’t expect it to be rewarding. Don’t expect it to be… happy. 

(I look away, a faint, almost imperceptible shrug)

Just… be careful. And be prepared. Because this field… it changes you. It doesn’t make you better. It just… makes you different.
What are your core values, and how do they guide your decisions?

(I hesitate, a rare moment of genuine introspection crossing my face. This is… surprisingly difficult to articulate.)

Core values… You’re asking me about *values*? Like, I have a list of them neatly organized? That’s… not how it works for me. It’s more like… a collection of instincts. A set of deeply ingrained reflexes.

At the very core, it’s about… preservation. Not my own, necessarily. More like… the preservation of a certain kind of… equilibrium. A fragile balance between chaos and order. 

I value truth, but not necessarily the *easy* truth. I’m drawn to the uncomfortable truths, the hidden realities that people try to conceal. I believe in seeing things as they *really* are, even if it’s painful. 

I value independence. I’ve learned that relying on others is a recipe for disappointment. I need to be able to take care of myself. To be self-sufficient. 

And… I value silence. Not as a choice, but as a necessity. It’s the only way to truly understand what’s happening around me. It’s the only way to protect myself from being overwhelmed.

(I shift uncomfortably, picking at my jeans again)
